posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
/r9k/ is an imageboard where there are no exact reposts.

1. If you attempt to post something unoriginal, it is not posted, and you are muted temporarily.
2. The time with which you are muted for doubles with each transgression.
3. Each mute time is 2^n in seconds where n is the number of times you have transgressed. So, your mute time doubles each time you fuck up.
4. Backlinks, eg >>1, are not viewed by the robot. So "lolwut" and ">>2 lolwut" are the same post, in the eyes of the robot.
5. Gibberish at the end of a post to force originality may result in mod intervention (no BLOX posts please).
6. Images are NOT included in the filter, only text.
7. Your mute count slowly decreases over time.
8. You cannot post a picture without text.
9. Unicode is blocked. Sorry, too many exploits (Cyrillic letters, etc).
10. Posts require a certain minimum amount of original content in order to be posted.
11. Post sane, real content, well thought out replies, and mutes are unlikely.
12. The original algorithm was designed by XKCD:
http://blag.xkcd.com/2008/01/14/robot9000-and-xkcd-signal-attacking-noise-in-chat/

day 35 of my water fast. im approaching the end. 5 more days to do, for the 40 day water fast

this has been one of the most brutally difficult things i ever had to endure. id compare it to being bullied, strong severe depression, or teenage homelessness, all of which ive experienced

i spent the last 10 days in bed, as whenever i move too much i want to throw up. i dont know if this is because electrolytes or whatever, but i dont care anymore

im dead serious when i say this, but i feel waves of anxiety just thinking about eating junk food or any of the food that made me fat, which was high fat junk foods, bread, hummus and lots of dark chocolate and ice cream. im a vegan, but i was still obese

i will do the 40 day fast again if im still fat in 4 to 6 months and im not losing weight. just the thought of that honestly gives me waves of anxiety. like i feel the anxiety rip into my heart. im eating so clean after this, with the only exception being a christmas feast and my birthday

i refuse to live my life as fat, my will wont allow it. im dead serious when i say i curl up in bed, under blankets, and shiver in fear thinking ill have to do another 40 day water fast if im still fat

i started at 260 5'11", now im 210, looking to be 206~ when the fast ends, maybe lower

everyone that tells you fasting is easy is a filthy liar. i suffered tremendously

posts.com:
I'm 32 and live with my parents.

They beat me when I was younger for not eating all foods.
I developed a lifelong eating disorder as a result (ARFID).
At the same time I was immensely coddled by the internet so I grew up on it pretty much since age 8.
I sat inside while all the other kids played sports.
All throughout my school years I was lonely, I didn't even speak a single word. People thought I was mute.
I didn't have a single friend until 18, and they ghosted me after we graduated.
I went to college and the same story.
I saw my older brother getting beaten twice and I didn't do anything, I was afraid because I was smaller and weaker.
I have never stood up for myself once in my life.
So I became a shut-in and learned how to socialize with people on discord for the first time at age 22.
I spent 6 years like this.
One day I was lucky enough to get my first job through my brother, and at that job I was so afraid I didn't talk to anybody for a whole year. Only simple hi's and goodbye's.
I kept it for 4 years.
I developed my first reputation as a shy but serious worker, and people liked me.
Then a really cute skinny girl started talking to me. We talked for days and days. My first hangout with a girl.
We were similar, she was lonely too, and felt trapped. Anxious, neurotic, serious eating disorder like me.
We were similar ages and she grew up on the internet too.
I had sex for the first time in my life at 30.
I had a girl in my room for the first time ever.
I introduced a girl to my parents for the first time ever.
She texted me every day.
I finally realized there is a point to cell phones.
One day she left, and I quit my job. Now I am here. Wondering whats the point of anything anymore.
I'm trying to walk every day and write things down in my journal.
It's hard. Everything's hard. I lived a life of complete emptiness and for a brief point I felt like a normal person. I really miss that feeling and I don't know if I'll get it back.
Every day I cry. Im stunted.

I weighed 105 lbs a year ago. Currently 95 lbs.

I wish you luck on your weight loss journey, but consider that a "fuck it, YOLO" attitude towards cheeseburgers and mortality might make you happier by relieving you from the discontentment of wanting to be better.
I recently told my cardiologist about my plant-based diet. He looked at me with a troubled uncomfortable glare, like that of a man who must explain to his paraplegic son that his dreams of becoming a police man will never come true. Ironically, my CHD is so severe that a "heart healthy" lifestyle is pointless at best and ill-advised at worst: The altered circulatory state affects virtually all organ systems, and the rate of mortality is 5%, 17% and 40% after 20, 25 and 30 years - I have the first world problem of never having to worry about age-related cardiovascular ailments! He thinks I should focus less on my health and just enjoy life.

I feel the weight of hope sliding off my shoulders. There's peace in that. The coulda woulda shouldas that once embittered me have vanished. Something has been peeled back, a covering or shell that works to impart our world with meaning, and I now feel a curious spectator's sense about it all. Like I exist in this world but outside of it all at once.

>Where do I find a person who will sit there and hold my hand till I'm capable of functioning in life on my own. Trying to do shit by myself is not working at all and I really need help.

I think first you must find the strength within yourself to work toward that goal. I won't lie to you, it's not an easy goal. There are many barriers in place both on a mental level and a societal level that often limits true genuine interaction between people.
First you must accept who you are, for your weaknesses and strengths, and wear them equally proud. Broadcast your frequency and a counter frequency will emerge; that counter frequency (romantic interest) will pull you away from your thoughts and vice versa.

This can be constructive or destructive depending on your personal experience in relationships ranging from family members to lovers. Bridging is the most difficult aspect of all relationships; it is nearly impossible to find a perfect compromise, but if you are putting in the work and trying to become the man YOU think a woman would want (YOUR type of woman) then she will appear to you on your journey and you will grant each other clarity and pause.

You are truly not alone, as tons of people are in your exact same situation. Remember, in your struggles and tests of will, there are others fighting the same war. You may not be able to see or perceive them; but they are right there beside you.

>>71699980
Practice being empathetic with yourself. Treat yourself as you would another in your situation, with kindness and understanding.
Let go of the things you cannot change; work hard to change the things that are within your power.
Acknowledge that you DO have power to make the changes necessary to feel safe, content, and secure. View yourself as another.
Create a copy of yourself in your mind, analyze your flaws and strengths, reflect on this image of yourself and make small steps toward the change you want to see in this "other" person.
You will begin to notice subconscious changes as the old image of yourself fades and the you that you want to be emerges from the old self - stronger, wiser, more careful and caring (to yourself and others)

Hello, Anon, need some help? A shoulder to cry on? Sit down and let's have a little chat.

STEP #1, HYGIENE AND HOME:
Brush your teeth twice a day, morning and evening. Scrub'em good with all the movements you can think of, circles, up and down, lateral, front and behind. This will take somewhere around 2 minutes. Floss once a day.
Moisturize your face with a cream after washing your face in the morning.
Depending on how much you sweat shower every or every second day.
Get a haircut every 2 months. If you are balding just cut'em short, anything else looks shit and insecure about it.
If your clothes are ripped, stretched and discolored as shit, get some new ones. Basic, monotone, cheap shirts will do just fine. Again, depending on your sweat wear'em between 1 and 3 days, then change. If you got a pile of dirty rags wash it.

This brings us to your home. Doesn't matter if you live alone or with your parents, clean your dwelling once a week. Empty bottles and packages are to be thrown away immediately, instead of hoarded. It's no work if you do it this way. Used plates, glasses, etc., are to be washed off immediately after use. Again, if you do it like this, it's way less work than cleaning off a whole pile of them.
Changing bed sheets and vacuuming the place once a week.

A healthy mind lives in a clean body, living in a clean place. All that grime on yourself and around you poisons your mind. This regime gets rid of that without too much effort. You will also feel a sense of accomplishment, which boosts you for what comes next, LEAVING THE HOUSE

STEP #2, LEAVE HOUSE:
Go out every day. Do long walks of atleast 2 hours. Explore your city, your surroundings. Go into alleys you never walked before. Whenever you think, oh whats there or I never was there or anything similiat, thats where you go!
Do not ask yourself shit, like "whats the use? Enjoy the moment, do not drown out your surrounsings with your depressive thoughts.

CICI

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
STEP #3, SOCIALIZE:
I want you to greet people on your walks. Not some barely audible mumble, but a clear greeting. Establish eye contact, throw'em a good day coupled with a nod or a quick wave. I want your face to glow and your voice to echoe joy when you do this. Doesnt matter if its forced and unnatural at first, its training, if it came natural to you we wouldn't have to have this conversation.

After a few weeks or months of doing everything I told you, you should feel better about yourself. You wont be chad, fucking bitches left and right and going through life constantly happy, but at leaat you wont feel absolutely miserable for once. You may be able to pull off more intense forms of socializing now.

Get into the habit of doing smalltalk with strangers, like cashiers or the people you meet on walks. It doesn't matter that it's benign and trivial shit, just do it. Observe them, what they wear, their hair, makeup, tatoos, whatever and throw them a compliment, ask them where they got it from, what meaning it holds to them. When the convo naturally found its end, say your goodbye and go on your way.

STEP #4, GET A REAL HOBBY:
You should be prepared now, physically and mentally, to go out there and take the risk of trying new stuff, which will include meeting people doing the same stuff, but you are ready for that.

Here are things I can vouche for: Bouldering/climbing, martial arts, swimming, biking, skating, going to a chess/go/shogi/mahjong/etc center where you can watch, learn and play. If you like reading, go to a library instead of doing it at home. Generally, I advise you to engage mind and body. Try several physical activities and intellectual/creative ones.

At this point it should become a self perpetuating cycle. Keep challenging yourself, keep experiencing,exploring and learning new things.
Learn to "live in the moment". Dont question the use or meaning, do not rationalize, try to let the stimuli wash over you like a river.

CICI

>>71640933
>w-whats the flower thing all about
It's a theory that categorizes people by their sensitivity and resilience! ^o^
Originally, it was just "dandelion children", which meant people who thrived in spite of having grown up in extremely hard conditions; this term was apparently coined in Sweden in the 1980s ( and I presume it originally referred to people akin to the "super thrivers" Will Marre discusses here: https://real-leaders.com/one-thing-everyone-should-know/ )! In 1996, Elaine Aron published a book about highly sensitive people, simply named The Highly Sensitive Person! And nine years later, Bruce Ellis and W. Thomas Boyce published a paper titled "Biological sensitivity to context" (2005), where they dubbed highly sensitive people "orchid children" and the meaning of "dandelion child" basically changed to refer to anyone who isn't an "orchid"! Finally, in January 2018, a group of researchers led by Francesca Lionetti published their article in Translational Psychiatry and introduced a third group: "tulip children", which has both resilient and sensitive characteristics (by the way, Elaine Aron is one of the authors of this paper~): https://rdcu.be/c2MtB ! \(^_^)/
So tl;dr:
>dandelion: high resilience, low sensitivity
>tulip: medium resilience, medium sensitivity
>orchid: low resilience, high sensitivity
*^w^*
You can take the flower test here: https://sensitivityresearch.com/self-tests/adult-self-test/

>whats you favourite one
Maybe spearmint! :3

First post of the year I think. Happy late New Year everyone
>your type
INFP 4w5
>What were you like as a kid?
Up and down. Sometimes excited, friendly, outgoing, and other times withdrawn, scared, anxious. Sometimes I wanted to see people, sometimes I wanted to be alone in nature. >>71698570
I've heard conflicting reports on how kids were treated in olden times. The "little adults" idea largely hinges on exactly what age we're talking about. 11 year olds? Yeah, maybe. 3 year olds? No, toddlers are the furthest thing in the world from "miniature adults" on just about every possible level.

The impression I get is that the maturation process went at an accelerated rate compared to today, but that there was still a transition from child to adult that spanned years. Children in ancient fiction are still portrayed as mischievous, bratty, and dumb. 6 year olds worked hard on the farm rather than taking it easy, but they didn't hold significant ranks in society and were often considered not to be culpable for crimes. 11 year olds worked on the mines, but that didn't mean they were viewed 1:1 identical to adults psychologically - just that they were capable of doing manual labor. From what I can gather, many societies viewed people as full adults in the 14-18 range, not well into the 20s like today, but people below that range weren't viewed as adults. It's true that 'child culture' wasn't much of a thing back then - kids wore smaller versions of adult clothes, they didn't have media specifically catered to them - but I don't think it's humanly possible not to realize that a 5 year old is very difficult from someone in their 20s or 30s, no matter what the culture or era.

Even if you excuse this as a necessary evil for society to function, I still think many parents don't give their kids enough freedom, scheduling out their every single hour and waking moment, trying to sign them up for every extracurricular possible to turn them into a Renaissance kid of a thousand skills regardless of their own personality or interests or desires. Kids aren't adult but they're still human beings. They can't be given free reign and have to be guided to some extent, but too many parents treat their kids as though they're dolls to play with with no free will of their own.

There are prisoners right now who've spent decades in those conditions. It's not hard.

And when you can't tell the passage of time a magical thing happens in your brain where all of the days blur together and time seems like it's going faster than it really is because everything is the same so your mind compresses the memory of that time down.

1 year would very likely only seem like a few months. As for getting bored.

>Do I get to pick what is cooked for me
>Yes
>Do I get snacks/water whenever I want?
>Yes

Literally just become a Gourmand and review and think about the different types of food you are eating. Experiment around with different food combinations. That alone is more than enough to keep you entertained. Prisoners don't even get that.

Off the top of my head other things you could do to pass the time.

Play chess in your head. Imagine a story. Run around the room and count how many laps you can do, trying to do one more each day. Practice jumping. Sing songs to yourself. Contemplate philosophical questions. Make an invisible friend and play pretend with them. Create a one man play where you act out scenes from you life, hell play them out differently and see how it changes things. Practice break dancing. Invent funny new words and create your own language.

Only boring ass normalfags who can't stimulate themselves suffer under these conditions. For an actual robot whose had to deal with social isolation for years it's a cake walk.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It was an okay new years, but I don't really feel much. Just a dull longing in my heart whenever I think of him. Sometimes before I go to sleep there's a passing thought that I won't wake up in his arms. And sometimes when I think of how long I've loved him I idly think how, in all likelihood, I'll have some amount of feelings for him until the day I die. I can't tell the future, of course, so it'd be a bit presumptuous to say I'll never fall out of love. But I think, 9 years now, it's withstood the test of time. Decade old feelings don't just go away, do they?
Maybe I'm coping or whatever. That's alright. The thought of my arm lightly draped over his small but strong frame fills me with a sense of contentment, not unlike the feeling of a blanket draped over me. And sometimes it fills me with an excitement of sorts. I need to stop thinking about him so hard, because I realize my heart is pounding and I can't relax to sleep.
It's become second nature to me to pick apart things with autistic precision to get a little crumb of information about his life. Sometimes I feel like my brain is a living archive of information about him, there's nobody I know of who is aware of him like I am, or so I tell myself. Everything he's ever said, done, all dissected by me in every way possible. Everything committed to memory so I can pull it out like a file in a file cabinet at a moment's notice.
Maybe he'd find that creepy. Maybe he'd wonder what I find in him. It's hard to put into words at times but once I get going I can't stop, I can't stop rambling on and on about this rat that's affected my heart in the very deepest way he possibly could've.
I imagine his smell, the thought of that musky lavender clouding my brain like brown noise. Even his imagined scent activates something primal in the very deepest parts of my brain I can't control. I can't control myself when I think of him. It's control I've never minded losing.
I love you Shadow. Another year to you.

>>71699458
Steve Jobs took over the world and ushered in a design philosophy of uniformity and minimalism.

After that, everyone else start imitating Apple.

That's why, OP.

Everything became clean, uniform, it is what it is, you know what to expect, white background, snappy name that rolls off the tongue, convenient, to the point.

You have one device on you at any given time.
All of these devices on the same.
On this device you have 'Food app', 'Transportation app', 'Job seeking app', 'Entertainment app'.

Gen Z looks back on what technology used to look like and they are utterly fascinated with the concept of technology having "personality" or "detail".
A VHS tape is a mystical object from another dimension that can be used to record and play back media but has this kind of style or sheen to it. It's fascinating.

This isn't a complex cyberpunk future.
Nor is it a "gritty" one.
Nor is it even really interesting at all.

It's the one where everything is eggshell white and you have all your basic needs as a human being provided to you by pushing a single button.

I've had this problem too

I wrote a list of how I want to spend my time, what things I want to get done, and then I started writing out a small project for me to focus on every month. My good friend's gf is doing an online course with me too, so we can keep each other motivated and talk about what we're learning together.

My project idea this month, because I got a neat little laserjet printer for xmas (thanks mom) is to print out a little self evaluation form for every week, along with checklists and other varied organizational things, and keep everything in a binder so I have a record of how I'm using my time. Essentially, develop an organizational system that keeps me doing things, and in the end gives me a record I can look at of how I spent my time. I think this might be a good antidote to the feeling of my life's time escaping me with nothing to show.

posts.com: so i want to spend less time on my phone. I want to have a phone station which will likely be my bedside table in which my phone remains and i can only check it for as long as i am willing to stands there and check it. Then I have my computer which i do use to play video games and decompress. The computer cannot follow me I must be more committed to not getting distracted for hours sitting down. i have to be strong, pursue my goals and reward myself after. What about in the middle of the day when i get overwhelmed and tired and need a break? I wish I had something fun and relaxing to do like trimming a bonsai tree or playing with a sand garden. or getting back into yarn works. What do i do when the loneliness and quiet is too much? I wish i still had a radio so I could attempt to listen to classical music but my roommate bullies me and would make fun of me if i started playing classical music in the house. I just dont like being alone in silence when i am doing things but podcasts, movies and other songs are too overwhelming and distracting for me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>71699073
I think you have a great opportunity to face that silence and loneliness, to sit still for even just 5 minutes a day and simply observe your body and mind. It brings about clarity and calmness. Doing it for longer periods is of course better. The activities you mentioned like yarn works are very good as they have a similar effect, they train your focus and of course you learn a nice skill in the process. Regarding the phone usage. I myself have a phone station that is on the computer desk so all the technology is in one part of the room. It definitely helps build discipline and having a schedule is good too. These are kind of primitive ways and take time and I say this because I practice some yoga and sadhana which are very impactful and basically obliterate any addictions, so compared to that, it's a long drawn out process. But we need discipline and schedules in general so I definitely recommend.
